Shah alleged that the director of Hyderabad-based Fabtraxt Designs Pvt Ltd Rajesh Varma and his employee Ravi Teja got in touch with him last year through email and placed a requisition for 274 laptops on rent. They took the laptops but neither paid the rent nor returned them.

Shah visited Fabtraxt company in Hyderabad on February 24 this year and learnt Rajesh Varma had allegedly sold the company. Shah estimated his firmâs loss at over Rs 70 lakh.

headline: Strikers protest at district headquarters; govt remains cold to their demands
content: BENGALURU: Transport employees on Monday staged protests across the state even as their indefinite strike entered the 13th day.The protests at district headquarters and depots hit bus operations through the day. However, transport department officials said there was less passenger footfall on Monday compared to Sunday due to rising Covid cases. âPassenger traffic was less on Monday. Some crew members didnât report for duty, anticipating protests at depots. They were scared since several buses have been damaged across the state and protesters are assaulting staff on duty. They will join work from Tuesday,â said a transport department official.While the protesting employees signalled that they are open to negotiations and want to resolve the strike before Wednesday, the government seemed to be in no mood to compromise. The government says it will consider talks only after employees return to work. However, employees feel they will lose bargaining power once the strike is called off.Home minister Basavaraj Bommai on Monday said he had a meeting with Kodihalli Chandrashekar, who is leading the transport strike. âI have asked him to withdraw the strike and also explained to him the present financial situation of the state,â he said.According to sources, the finance department said the government cannot provide more than 10% pay hike. âWe can provide only 8%-10% wage hike,â said an official. However, there is no clarity on withdrawal of cases and orders related to dismissals, suspensions and transfers.âNormally, we withdraw these cases and orders following negotiations with protesters. But no decision has been taken in this regard so far,â the sources added.However, Chandrashekar insisted they will continue the strike. âWe had a discussion with the home minister. He said he will talk to the CM and the issue will be resolved in two days. We have given them three choices: Provide government employee status or implement the 6th Pay Commission report or enforce a 2004 labour court order on salary revision (20% hike with 6% interest),â he pointed out.Chandrashekar said many employees were arrested on Monday. âWe are conducting peaceful protests and have nothing to do with those damaging buses,â he added.Asked if there is any plan to withdraw the strike, he said: âThe CM is in hospital and the transport minister is not in Bengaluru as he is in quarantine. They will be back in a few days. The government is trying to suppress the strike instead of negotiating with employees.âIn Bengaluru, staff members who came to protest were detained by police. However, the protesters have withdrawn the jail bharo (fill prisons) plan due to increasing Covid cases.Meanwhile, KSRTC in a statement said the striking workers were agitated by the rising numbers of operational buses and hence damaging vehicles.âMany protesting employees attacking duty staff and damaging buses have been caught by police and strict action is being taken. Three KSRTC buses were damaged at Harohalli in Kanakapura and two duty staff were assaulted on Monday morning. We will provide adequate protection to the duty staff and violators will face severe consequences,â it said.KSRTC on Monday removed 251 trainee employees from the selection list for not reporting to duty and disrupting services.âBMTC taking strict actionâBMTC managing director C Shikha, in a statement, said BMTC bus operations have been improving in the past few days â 873 on Friday, 1,155 on Saturday and 1,406 on Sunday.âSome of the employees involved in the strike are spreading fake messages on revoking suspension and dismissal orders. There is no such provision or thinking at the government level,â she said.Shikha said the protesters are spreading fake news with regard to the high courtâs involvement in resolving the strike in the next two days. âThis is a last-ditch attempt to stretch the protest to Monday and Tuesday,â she added.âBMTC has been taking strict action against those who are encouraging the strike. Post suspension/ dismissal, many employees have communicated they did not come to work fearing the union... Adequate police protection will be given to those employees returning to work. All staffers should immediately join duty in public interest,â she added.

headline: Demand outstrips Karnataka’s oxygen quota
content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

BENGALURU: At a time when the Centre has asked states to ban production of oxygen for industrial use and enhance production of medical oxygen, Karnataka could face scarcity as oxygen produced in the state is being exported to other states.

On Monday, the Union government held a video conference with chief secretaries and heads of industries departments in all states to bring them up to date on the Centreâs directives with regard to medical oxygen.

At the meeting, Karnataka was told it will be allocated 300 tonnes of oxygen from the national pool, although seven companies in the state have the capacity to produce as much as 812 tonnes of oxygen. The allocation sent the state government into a tizzy as daily consumption in the state has shot up to 305 tonnes as of Monday.

âOn Sunday we used 280 tonnes and today it was 305 tonnes. If we are allocated only 300 tonnes of oxygen and with cases surging, we may face a serious crisis very soon if higher allocation is not made,â said a senior government official who attended the meeting with the cabinet secretary.

Sources in the industries department said the state government has placed a request for 1000 tonnes and the Centreâs allocation is way short. As a result of this decision, the Karnataka government is planning to seek a ban on export of oxygen to other states.

âThe government will write to the cabinet secretary, the Union health ministry and the department for promotion of industries and trade (DPIT) seeking a ban on export of oxygen to other states,â said another government official.

Data accessed by TOI shows Karnatakaâs oxygen production for all purposes stands at around 598 tonnes per day from seven companies in four districts. Of this, medical oxygen is 410 tonnes which is supplied to hospitals in Karnataka. But with the Centre banning industrial use, the state can produce 598 tonnes of medical oxygen.

Jindal Steel Works ( JSW ) in Ballari alone produces 440 tonnes. Incidentally, oxygen is a byproduct of the steel manufacturing industry.

headline: Hospital in Bengaluru hands over wrong body to family members
content:
Ambulance crew wait at a crematorium in Bengaluru as fatalities surged on Monday. Bereaved kin say drivers dem... Read More

BENGALURU: In a bizarre incident, the family of a 68-year-old woman, who had died after from Covid-19 on Monday, received the wrong body and death certificate at Rajarajeswari Medical College and Hospital.

Family members say, Jayalakshmamma, a resident of Yelahanka, was unwell for a few days and was admitted to a private hospital before being shifted to Rajarajeswari hospital after testing positive for Covid.

Ramu, her younger brother, told TOI, âWe moved her to Rajarajeswari Medical College and Hospital on Sunday evening. Since she was Covid-19 positive, staff told us that family members will not be allowed to stay with the patient. Around 3.15am on Monday, we received a call informing us that my sister had breathed her last.â

The family members reached the hospital around 8am and went to the mortuary where the body was stored. âThe hospital gave us a death certificate as well,â Ramu said. âSince it was a Covid case, the body was wrapped in PPE. Jayalakshmammaâs sons could not come, but they wanted us to share a final picture of hers. We went to take the photo only to find that it was not my sisterâs body,â Ramu said.

He said after the incident they were not sure whether his sister was dead. âWe felt the hospital authorities were lying to us,â he said.

Nagamma, another relative, said, âWe confronted hospital staff, but they told us to come back after two hours. They were adamant. If a person is dead, I do not know why hospital staff need two hours to show us the body. After two hours, the body was handed over to us. What if we had not checked?â

Ramu also said ambulances were charging hefty fees. âWe had to pay Rs 8,000 to shift the body to the crematorium. How can people from economically weaker sections cope? The government needs to look into the matter,â he said.

Dr Naveen Shivappa, principal, Rajarajeshwari Medical College and Hospital, admitted an error had been made. He said there were four deaths in 6-7 hours at the hospital. âWe have initiated an inquiry and are checking what went wrong,â he said.

Dr Shivappa said the hospital is facing a severe shortage of staff as about 20% had left recently. âWe were managing okay, but then there was a sudden spike in inflow of patients. Every day, about 40 Covid patients are brought here. Given the situation, we are doing our best,â he said. He said the body was handed over to the family in 20 minutes and not two hours as the family claimed.

headline: Covid-19: Karnataka's daily average much higher than last year’s peak
content:
In a reiteration that the rate of infection in the second wave is higher than the first, data shows Karnatakaâ... Read More

BENGALURU: In a reiteration that the rate of infection in the second wave is higher than the first, data shows Karnatakaâs average of daily cases so far in April is the highest since the outbreak.

At 9,114 cases per day, the daily average is 500 more than the highest number recorded during the peak in 2020 â 8,644 in September. Bengaluru numbers also show a similar trend but the difference between the current surge and that in 2020 is far more acute in the capital city. From 3,451 in September 2020 it has risen to 6,211 now â 80% higher.

Going by the current rate, Karnataka is expected to add at least 1.1 lakh cases this month, of which more than 80,000 may be in Bengaluru. That the stateâs active cases â more than 1.3 lakh â are at a higher level than the peak of 2020 is also concerning.

With the government suggesting the second wave would peak in the first week of May, experts anticipate a significant surge in deaths given that healthcare infrastructure is already showing signs of severe stress.

Dr Giridhara Babu, member, technical advisory committee (TAC), said: âThere is already a shortage of beds especially for those needing critical care and with cases only rising, the number of deaths will certainly increase if the transmission chain isnât broken to reduce the stress on hospitals.â

Another expert said that the government lost focus late last year when cases began to dip despite projections of an impending second wave. Dr HM Prasanna, president, Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association (PHANA), said beds are all filling up quickly and the shortage of medical oxygen is not helping critical care treatment.

Compared to the more than 9,000 cases this month, the average of daily cases in March was just 1,475 â 517% less than April. Bengaluru too has reported a massive spike compared to March.

The average of daily cases had dipped continuously from November in Karnataka â from 6,825 in October, it had dipped drastically to 1,927 in November and from there to 1,073 in December before hitting the low threedigit figure in January and February.

Dr V Ravi, nodal officer for genome sequencing of SARS-CoV2 and member, TAC, said: âThis is exactly what Iâd been warning the government about. Unlike in 2020, we should have used the experience from last year and prepared in advance for this, but the government did not do that. It is now clear that there will be more deaths, many of which could have been prevented had there been proper planning.â

Ravi and another expert TOI spoke with emphasised the need for effective home monitoring of patients to prevent further stress on the healthcare system.

âOxygen saturation must be monitored every day and doctors need to call those in home isolation to ensure timely treatment and to save lives,â Dr Ravi said. âAt present, in the absence of this, patients are turning up very late to hospitals. This does two things: One, it makes it very difficult for doctors to save them, and two, such people will need critical care beds which could have been avoided,â he added.

headline: Active Covid cases in Bengaluru shoot past 1-lakh mark
content: BENGALURU: The active Covid-19 caseload in Bengaluru breached the 1-lakh mark on Monday, something that had never happened even during the peak of last yearâs first wave and an indication that infections are spreading much faster.Currently Pune, which has the countryâs highest active caseload at 1.2 lakh cases, is the only district ahead of Bengaluru. Besides, four other districts in Karnataka â Bidar, Kalaburagi, Mysuru and Tumakuru â have more than 3,000 active cases.As on Sunday (April 19), Indiaâs total active caseload had reached 19,29,329. Of these, five states â Maharashtra , Chhattisgarh, Uttar Pradesh, Karnataka and Kerala â together accounted for 63.1% of the cases. Karnatakaâs share of the countryâs active caseload is nearly 7%.Experts TOI spoke with say the only way to efficiently handle the increasing caseload is to categorise patients depending on the care they need and ensure sufficient beds.âIf 15,000 cases are reported in Bengaluru every day and if say 90% are fit enough for home isolation, a minimum 1,500 patients will need to be hospitalised,â said a doctor working on the BBMP expertâs committee. âAt the current rate, 1,500 beds are not falling vacant every day. It takes a minimum 4-5 days to discharge a Covid-infected patient from hospital. Saving lives will become much harder from here on,â the doctor said.In the past 10 days, a majority of the fresh cases in Bengaluru were reported from BBMPâs south zone (15,811) which accounts for 19% of all cases, followed by west and east zones which account for 15% each.Karnatakaâs Covid-19 technical advisory committee (TAC) has suggested that the government order select private hospitals to set up operations in hotels, which are stepdown hospitals equipped with oxygen beds.âThis has been done in Mumbai and Delhi,â said a TAC member. âNot every patient can be accommodated in hospitals henceforth and hence we need a system between hospitals and Covid Care Centres. These hotel-Covid care centres will have doctors and nurses and can be managed by the staff of private hospitals. They will be nothing but units of the hospitals in hotels,â the member said.The biggest challenge is to accommodate new patients in need of admission, said Dr BK Vijendra, chief health officer, BBMP. âA meeting with all elected representatives has been held,â Dr Vijendra said, adding that the government will take appropriate measures.Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes Association (PHANA) said more restrictions are needed to break the chain of transmission. âEven if fresh cases come down by 10%, that will be a huge relief. Most private hospitals have limited scope to scale up. Instead, better utilisation of 10 medical colleges that have the infrastructure can be done and 8,000 beds can be created,â said Dr HM Prasanna, president PHANA. He said private hospitals are already stretched to capacity.

headline: Karnataka: Families of victims wait for hours to say final goodbyes
content:
Ambulances queue up, relatives with dead bodies rue lack of beds

Woman curator out to help

Not enough space

BENGALURU: It's 2.30pm on Monday at the Indian Christian Cemetery on Hosur Road. A woebegone family is waiting beside an ambulance which has their 16-year-old girl, a school student, who succumbed to Covid complications on Sunday.They're in a queue, waiting for their turn to lay to rest their beloved Preeti from Cox Town who was admitted to Bowring hospital three days ago with Covid complications. "She developed fever and cough and we rushed her to hospital. But she died on Sunday," said a relative. After Preeti, there were seven more Covid bodies waiting in ambulances outside Gate No. 4 of the burial ground. A family from Rajajinagar bid goodbye to their matriarch, 70-year-old Pappamma, who died on Sunday in a city hospital."On Sunday, we had 11 Covid burials and today, there have been 10 so far. This year, we're seeing more young people who died of Covid," said cemetery supervisor Naga.With the Covid death count rising by the day, crematoria and burial grounds are seeing long queues of ambulances with bodies. Places like the Kudlu crematorium are extending cremation into the wee hours of the next day. Thereâs a long queue with families of victims waiting for hours. âIt takes almost an hour to cremate a body. There was a huge queue on Sunday as a result of which the cremation went on till late into the night as bodies kept coming,â a caretaker at this BBMP facility said.On Monday afternoon, there were ambulances waiting and many relatives who accompanied bodies lamented the lack of beds, oxygen cylinders and proper care for victims. âWe had to struggle for a bed and an oxygen cylinder. While we shifted him from one place to another to find a bed, he passed away,â said an enraged relative of a 40-year-old victim at the crematorium.Amid the silence at the Indian Christian Cemetery, a woman does her best to console the families. Anne Morris, 43, a canine trainer and curator at the burial ground, joined in mid-February to help families. âThis is also a service and Iâm honoured to do my bit for victims,â she said.Anne often lends her shoulder to carry bodies along with other workers and supervises grave-digging work. Covid victims are buried 10ft under, not 6ft, which is the norm.âWeâve almost run out of space to bury Covid victims. Cases are increasing and itâs taking a toll on funeral workers here,â said Anne, who has been infected a couple of times and even lost her sense of taste.

headline: Karnataka: Centenarian lexicographer G Venkatasubbaiah dead
content:
G Venkatasubbaiah

BENGALURU: Writer and critic G Venkatasubbaiah , who was popular as a 'walking encyclopedia of Kannada language and culture' for his contribution to the world of lexicography, passed away at age 107 here on Monday.

Suffering from renal problems for the past few days, the centenarian died around 1.15am, his family said. He had compiled 12 dictionaries, edited 60 books and produced many works on dictionary science in Kannada. His dictionaries include those on Kannada phrases, idioms, and information on the usage and history of dialects.

Venkatasubbaiah was born in a family of scholars on August 23, 1913 in Ganjam village of Srirangapatna in Mandya district. After his post-graduation, he worked as teacher at a municipal school in his hometown. From there, he taught high school students in Davanagere, and then took up a job at Maharaja's College in Mysuru. Later, he moved to Vijaya College in Bengaluru where he worked until his retirement in 1973.

Venkatasubbaiah, who has been honoured with Padma Shri and Kannada Sahitya Akademi award, had served as president of the Lexicographical Association of India for 17 years. In 2011, he presided over the 77th Akhila Bharata Kannada Sahitya Sammelana held in Bengaluru.

Lexicographer had met Gandhi as a teenager

Venkatasubbaiah became a household name for his popular column in a Kannada newspaper detailing the nuances of the language. It was later brought out as a book.

A follower of Mahatma Gandhi, Venkatasubbaiah had met him as a teenager when he was about to address a gathering in Madhugiri in 1927. Heonce recalled how he was assigned to make arrangements for Gandhiâs stay in Madhugiri and how many people from economically weaker sections donated for the freedom struggle and participated in it.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi led the mourners. âDemise of professor G Venkatasubbaiah has left a huge void in Kannada literature. He was a prolific writer and thinker who made many efforts to popularise Kannada. He was passionate about his work and inspired many youngsters. Condolences to his family and admirers. Om Shanti,â Modi tweeted.

headline: Only 15 of 591 ICU beds for virus cases vacant in Bengaluru
content:
Patients are coming in at last minute; 90% in hospitals are critical: Doctor

BENGALURU: With daily cases surging and patients under treatment at an all-time high in Bengaluru, dedicated Covid-19 beds across facilities are getting filled up rapidly with ICU occupancy at a worrying 98%.As of April 19, some 6,138 beds have been dedicated for Covid patients at 86 Bengaluru facilities â across government and private hospitals and medical colleges, and Covid Care Centres (CCCs). Of them, only 1,328 or 21.6% were vacant. Of the dedicated beds, 591 are ICU and 2,304 are HDU (high-dependency unit) beds. Only 2% (15) of the ICU beds and 9% of HDUs are vacant as of date. The data, part of BBMP âs Covid bed management database, is up to 12pm on Monday. It gets updated near real-time.According to the Private Hospitalsâ and Nursing Homesâ Association, the difference between HDUs and ICUs is in terms of monitoring and type of ventilators. HDUs have one nurse for four patients; ICUs have one nurse for every two and, in some cases, for each patient. ICUs have invasive ventilators and a doctor round the clock. Both ICU and high-dependence units require oxygen.No less than 76% of the 5,560 beds listed for Covid care are in private facilities and the rest at two CCCs. The state government is trying to augment this by issuing diktats to private hospitals to allocate more beds, but with no great success.Citizen complaints have been pouring in, and many have reached out to volunteer groups seeking help in getting Covid beds. Ameen-e-Mudassar, part of a citizen volunteer group Emergency Response Team in Bengaluru, posted an emotional video on Monday urging people to stay indoors. âThere is absolute chaos. Several hospitals are discharging patients in ICUs as they donât have oxygen while getting an ICU bed itself has become nearly impossible. We know of patients whoâve tried 50-60 hospitals, there are queues outside hospitals, so please stay indoors,â Mudassar said.In many cases, hospitals cite existing occupancy for being unable to divert beds for Covid, and this is especially true for critical-care beds. An advocate seeking bed for a relative said private hospitals informed them that BBMP has taken over the beds and is dilly-dallying over allotment.Phana president Dr HM Prasanna admitted to problems with critical-care beds and said lack of home monitoring of cases is resulting in patients coming in at the last moment, requiring high-dependency units, if not ICUs. âLast year, around 50% of patients in hospitals at any given time were not critical; this time, nearly 90% are critical.âOccupancy in general beds is also high. Of the 578 beds at two CCCs, only 14% are vacant; of the 2,666 general-category beds across facilities, 62% are occupied.Dr V Ravi, member, technical advisory committee, said: âThe rate at which cases are growing, the government must arrange for more beds. People should consult doctors before it is too late and to prevent need for ICU. They must regularly check for oxygen levels at home and consult doctors at the slightest change because deterioration occurs very quickly.â

headline: 4 sell Remdesivir at exorbitant prices; held
content:
According to police, the accused are selling Remdesivir injections whose revised MRP is Rs 3,490 for Rs 23,000... Read More

HYDERABAD: Task force sleuths arrested four persons for indulging in illegal sale of Remdesivir injections at exorbitant prices on Tuesday.

Central Zone team of Task force arrested three accused, Mohammed Abdul Hafeez, 52, owner of Sardar Medical Hall in Nampally, Sk Jilani, 27, a salesperson at Sardar Medical Hall and their associate, Md Bin Saleem, 51, a businessman from Nampally for selling Remdesivir injections for Covid-19 patients at higher price. Police seized four Remdesivir (Covifor) injections along with a scooter and three cell phones from the accused.

According to police, the accused are selling Remdesivir injections whose revised MRP is Rs 3,490 for Rs 23,000 to customers without maintaining a record.

While the accused were waiting at Murgi Market in Nampally to deliver the Remdesivir injection to a client, police arrested them and seized four vials from their possession.

Meanwhile the West Zone Task force sleuths arrested Shaik Mazhar, 33, who runs a medical store at Rehmath Nagar in Yousufguda while he was trying to sell Remdesivir injection to customers for Rs 35,000 a vial.

Police team nabbed Mazhar near Olive Hospital in Langar Houz when he arrived there to sell the drug to the clients and seized six vials of Covifor from his possession.

headline: EC should postpone municipal polls: Cong
content:
Telangana Congress election committee chairman Marri Shashidhar Reddy on Tuesday urged the Telangana State Ele... Read More

HYDERABAD: Stating that the night curfew imposed by the government should be taken as an example to check spread of coronavirus, Telangana Congress election committee chairman Marri Shashidhar Reddy on Tuesday urged the Telangana State Election Commissioner C Partha Sarathi to postpone the polls to seven urban local bodies and nine wards.

Not only the lakhs of voters and political leaders but also 9,000-odd employees drafted for polling duties and another 3,000 police personnel and their families stand the risk of getting infected with coronavirus if elections are held during the alarming surge of Covid during the second round,â Shashidhar Reddy said.

âAs the polling personnel have to reach the polling stations one day before the polling day and they have to stay that night there itself we can imagine the agony and plight of polling personnel and their families. These elections could be super spreaders. We request the State Election Commission to postpone the ensuing elections to save the lives of the public otherwise the State Election Commission and State Government will be held responsible for any harm caused to the people,â Shashidhar Reddy said.

He said the State Election Commission and state government have taken the unilateral decision to conduct these elections without taking into consideration the opinion of political parties and representatives of the employees and others.

Though the High Court expressed its view that it will not interfere in the poll process and said that it is for the State Election Commission and State Government to take a decision in this regard. However, the Court, in another petition, came down heavily on the state government for not taking steps to reduce the gathering of the people in public places.

As the court specifically found fault with the state government for not taking steps to reduce gathering of people in public places, the SEC should reconsider postponing the proposed elections so that people will not be exposed to grave risk of infection with Covid-19.

âWe also draw your attention to the fact that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has tested positive for Coronavirus and is suspected to have been infected at a public meeting in Haliya during the election campaign in Nagarjuna Sagar assembly constituency. TRS candidate Nomula Bhagat and several leaders who were present on the dais have tested Covid positive,â Shashidhar Reddy said.

headline: Get ready for agitation against TRS: Cong MP
content:
The farmers have harvested their crops but the government has hardly set any procurement centres, Congress MP ... Read More

HYDERABAD: Bhuvanagiri MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy of the Congress has appealed to the farmers to get ready for an agitation against chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao-led TRS government which has not set up procurement centres in villages.

âUnless we launch an agitation, it looks unlikely that the state government will start set up procurement centres. CM KCR had promised to set up procurement centres and also procure every seed of paddy from the farmers. But now that the by-poll to Nagarjuna Sagar is over, the government is neglecting the issue of procurement centres,â Venkat Reddy alleged.

He also wrote a letter to CM KCR seeking to remind him that he had assured on the floor of the house that the state government will purchase paddy from the farmers by setting up procurement centres.

âThe farmers have harvested their crops but the government has hardly set any procurement centres,â he alleged.

"Also, the unseasonal rains in the past few days have damaged crops in large extents and quantities. As more rains have been forecast, directions should be issued to the chief secretary and other officials concerned to immediately start procurement of agriculture produce by setting up centres,â Komatireddy Venkat Reddy urged the CM in his letter.

headline: TRS, BJP should come clear on ties: Cong
content:
The BJP should either accept that it has friendly ties with the ruling TRS or there is infighting within the s... Read More

HYDERABAD: The Congress has made a fervent appeal to the people of Telangana to understand the âsecret friendly tiesâ between the TRS and BJP getting exposed now in view of the ensuing by-poll to Lingojiguda ward in the city.

âThe TRS has announced it will not contest against BJP in Lingojiguda ward. There is a strong suspicion among the people that it is a deal between TRS and BJP as part of which the saffron party fielded a weak candidate in Nagarjuna Sagar asembly constituency by poll held on Saturday. In a quid pro quo, the TRS said it will not field its candidate from Lingojiguda where in BJP is seeking to retain the seat in the by-poll,â said AICC secretary S A Sampath Kumar.

Former minister V Hanumanth Rao has said the Congress party has been saying that TRS and BJP are two sides of a coin.

âOur stand has been vindicated with BJP approaching the TRS working president and KTR obliging them," he said.

The Congress leaders alleged that BJP state president Bandi Sanjay has constituted a committee to look into the issue of party ex-MLC Ramchander Rao-led delegation going to TRS working president KT Rama Rao and also seeking Congress's help to make the Lingojiguda by-poll unanimous in favour of the saffron party.

âAll this looks like a political drama between the two parties. If the TRS is true in its claim that BJP is a rival party, then why has the ruling TRS not booked any cases against Bandi Sanjay for targeting chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao with unparliamentary language,â Sampath said.

The BJP should either accept that it has friendly ties with the ruling TRS or there is infighting within the saffron party at a senior level, Sampath demanded.

However, the BJP office has clarified that Ramchander Rao going to KTRâs place was not a planned visit.

The family members of BJP corporator-elect late Akula Ramesh Goud were going to KTRâs office when they saw Ramchander Rao and urged him to accompany them. Rao obliged. However, Bandi Sanjay appointed committee is looking into the issue and will submit a report, said the BJP leaders.

headline: 3 held for illegal sale of Remdesivir vials in Hyd
content: HYDERABAD: Task force sleuths arrested three persons for the alleged illegal sale of Remdesivir injections used for Covid-19 treatment. Two of the accused are employees of a pharma company manufacturing generic version of Remdesivir injection.Acting on specific information, a trap was laid at Begumpet. The accused, B Venkatesh, 27, field sales officer of the Hetero Healthcare and J Sharan Sai, 26, medical representative from Ram Nagar were arrested. They were in possession of 12 vials of Remdesivir injection. âBased on their confession, we arrested Sk Saleem Jaffar, 32, area business manager of Hetero Healthcare company, from his office in Kukatpally,â North Zone Task force inspector K Nageshwar Rao said.Police seized 12 vials of 100mg Remdesivir injections from their possession. According to police, Saleem Jaffar and Venkatesh hatched a plan to make easy money by illegally selling the vials in black market for a higher price.Sharan Sai came in contact with his former colleague, Jaffar and the latter agreed to sell the injection vial for Rs 15,000. âSharan has been selling the same for Rs 20,000 to needy customers and medical stores,â Task force DCP P Radha Kishan Rao said.On Monday, as per the instructions of Sai, Jaffar illegally procured 12 Remdesivir vials from their company outlet in Kukatpally and sent Venkatesh to Begumpet to deliver the vials to Sharan. Police arrested the trio and seized the vials.

headline: Covid-19: Telangana imposes night curfew from 9pm to 5am till May 1
content:
Telangana confirmed 5,926 fresh coronavirus cases, the highest ever in a single day. (PTI file photo)

HYDERABAD: The Telangana government on Tuesday announced a night curfew from 9pm to 5am, till May 1 in a bid to control the second wave of the pandemic.

The orders came a day after the high court pulled up the state for not taking any action to curb the spread of the pandemic.

The state reported 5,926 new Covid cases, the highest ever in a single day, pushing the tally to over 3.61 lakh, while the toll rose to 1856 with 18 more fatalities.

The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has issued an order laying down guidelines for effective control of Covid-19 providing for states to impose local restrictions to prevent the spread of Covid-19 based on the assessment of the situation.

The various measures to control Covid-19 in the state have been reviewed.

"It is decided to introduce night curfew in the state for the period from 9pm to next day till May 1 as a further measure to prevent the spread of Covid-19," read the order issued by the chief secretary, Telangana Somesh Kumar.

Movement of all persons shall be prohibited from 9pm onwards except people engaged in essential services, state and central government officers on emergency duty, medical personnel, pregnant women, patients and persons coming from/going to airports, railway stations, bus stands on the production of a valid ticket.

The order specified that during the above mentioned period all offices, firms, shops, establishments restaurants etc. shall close at 8pm except hospitals, diagnostic labs, pharmacies and those dealing with supply of essential services such as print and electronic media, telecommunications, internet services, broadcasting and cable services, IT and IT-enabled services.

Delivery of all goods through e-commerce, petrol pumps, LPG, CNG, petroleum and gas outlets, power generation, transmission and distribution, water supply and sanitation, cold storage and warehousing services, private security services and production units or services which require continuous process will be allowed.

"There shall be no restriction on inter-state and intra-state movement/transportation of essential and non-essential goods. No separate permission/pass will be required for such movement," the order read.

headline: In times of Covid, funeral business offers package deals for dead
content: HYDERABAD: Cremating the dead in times of Covid has become a lucrative business. With the mortality rate on a steady rise, a couple of corporate-styled funeral servicesâ firms â apart from local pandits and touts â are seen rolling out special packages on last rites, charging anywhere between Rs 30,000 and Rs 35,000 per ceremony.One of these companies â assuring end-to-end service across seven Indian cities â even has a complete customer support team in place at its headquarters, along with on-ground managers in every city, to handle its âordersâ.âWe will conduct the entire procedure for you â from picking up the body to arranging a vehicle, booking a slot at the crematorium (in Bansilalpet), organising a pandit and even getting the material required for the rites,â said Sampath Bangaram, city manager of the Bengaluru-based Anthyesti Funeral Services with offices in Chennai, Delhi, Jaipur among others. The package rate for Hyderabad: Rs 32,000.Much like many other e-commerce platforms, here too the âcustomerâ is first directed to the firmâs hotline number for registration. Then, based on location, he/she is patched a call with the city coordinator. The payment is made directly to the companyâs account.Funeral Seva Services, though limited to Hyderabad for now, too works on similar lines.It prides itself on offering âfuneral services at your doorstepâ and has a two different â gold and basic â packages listed on its website. The former, predictably, promises a more elaborate cremation.While the executive was hesitant to share too many details over telephone when TOI called posing as a client, he said: âWe are charging Rs 30,000 for Covid patients... itâs a risky job and getting slots at cremation sites is very difficult with the rush.â On being probed about the packages he added: âPlease send us your location, our executive will come there and give you details.âBoth these organisations said that they have been getting between 6 and 10 calls every day.Also arranging last rites for the Covid-infected are small-time funeral homes with tie-ups with crematoriums. âI will fix you up with the Erragadda facility. Though they are completely booked, we can help you get a slot. Charges will vary between Rs 30,000 and Rs 40,000 depending on what services you want,â said Raghu Kumar, introducing himself as a pandit.In fact, some claimed that there are many touts doing the rounds of hospitals, particularly government facilities, offering to conduct the last rites if paid handsomely â up to Rs 80,000 in some cases.

headline: K Chandrasekhar Rao, Nomula Bhagat, 60 others +ve after Sagar bypoll meeting
content: HYDERABAD: A public meeting that Telangana chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao held in Halia for the Nagarjuna Sagar assembly bypoll has led to the town becoming a Covid hotspot with over 60 people from the gathering testing positive. This includes KCR himself and the TRS candidate, Nomula Bhagat. Family members of politicians who attended the meeting too tested positive.Senior officials said KCR has mild symptoms at present and is being treated at his farmhouse in Erravelli. The public meeting was held on April 14. Voting for the bypoll was held on April 17 and the result is on May 2.KCR, who was suffering from mild fever, body aches and other symptoms since Sunday tested positive for Covid-19 in a rapid antigen test. Later, an RT-PCR test results too came back positive.Telangana chief secretary Somesh Kumar told TOI that a special team of doctors has been deputed to monitor KCRâs health. The staff and people who moved with him closely have also been asked to get themselves tested and go for home isolation for few days. All his personal staff tested negative.The Halia public meeting was organised with nearly one lakh people. KCR addressed the meeting as Nagarjuna Sagar was won by TRS in 2018 and the party has been taking all elections seriously after it suffered a shock defeat in the Dubbak assembly by-election in November, 2020.Nalgonda health officials said as many as 440 cases were reported on a single day from the district on Monday and 66 cases were from Halia. Sources said the primary reason could be many participants in the meeting did not wear masks and no social distancing was maintained.Besides Bhagat, other leaders like M C Koti Reddy and Kadari Anjaiah and their family members and scores of people got the infection at the meeting.âOf the 175 tests conducted at the primary health centre at Halia on Monday, 66 have tested positive,â Kondal Rao, Nalgonda district health and medical officer, told TOI.In Nalgonda district, the cases were just 27 on April 1 and rose to 208 on April 7.The cases crossed 300 a day in the second week of April at the time of public meeting, an official said.Nalgonda district minister G Jagadish Reddy and health minister Eatala Rajender will be holding a review meeting on Covid-19 cases on Tuesday. They will look at the rise in cases both in Suryapet and Nalgonda districts

headline: Act in 48 hours to curb Covid-19 spread or will step in: Telangana high court to KCR government
content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Monday gave 48 hours to the state government to take steps to combat the spiralling Covid-19 cases, failing which it will step in.It also directed the government to decide fast on enforcing night curfew and imposing strict curbs at shopping malls, function halls, clubs, restaurants, theatres, etc, to check the spread.Expressing concern over surge in positive cases all over the state, a bench of Chief Justice Hima Kohli and Justice B Vijaysen Reddy said: âWe would bring in a stricter Covid-19 regime if the state government does not display enough will power for reasons best known to it.âTalking tough, the CJ said that if the government does not display a Covid-appropriate behavior, then they will step in to ensure that a strict combat regime is implemented all over the state.The judges sought a report within 48 hours from the government on implementing strict crowd control methods and declaring certain areas as micro containment zones, besides imposing a ceiling on guests at marriages and shoppers at malls and clubs. The judges also asked the authorities to make a mention in the report about the returnees from Kumbh mela as to how many have been screened and how many sent to quarantine.Resuming the hearing in PILs related to Covid-19 treatment, the judges rejected the reports furnished by the director of public health (DPH) and director general of police (DGP) saying that they did not provide the information that was sought by the court.âWe asked the government to convey the number of RT-PCR tests being done, turnaround time, steps taken to cut down crowding at public congregations and reduce footfalls at restaurants, malls, function halls, marriages, clubs, theatres, etc. The report harps on efforts at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport, but it is silent on what was the government is doing to prevent the spread of the virus at bus stations, railway stations, state borders, etc,â the bench said. They also expressed dissatisfaction over non-furnishing of details on RT-PCR tests, district-wise figures, etc.When advocate general BS Prasad informed the court that DPH and health secretary were present before the court, the judges said their claim of setting up 14 RT-PCR labs was far from inspiring. âWe are in the thick of a second wave. When will you make them functional,â they sought to know. To this, the health secretary said the process to procure the lab technology is still under way and it could take three more weeks to procure them and make the labs functional.The case was adjourned to April 23.

headline: P&G’s Hyderabad facility first in India to go solar
content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: FMCG biggie Procter & Gamble on Monday said it has commissioned its first in-house solar power plant in India at itâs Hyderabad manufacturing facility. P&G said this is the companyâs first manufacturing site in India and only the fifth site globally to house a solar power plant.

The 1MW solar power plant, spread over 16,000 sq mt, comprises nearly 3,000 solar panels and will reduce P&Gâs carbon footprint by around 1030 metric tonnes annually, the company said. The Hyderabad site, which is located on the cityâs outskirts in Kothur mandal of Rangareddy district, is P&Gâs largest manufacturing plant in India. The facility is focused on manufacturing the companyâs fabric care brands like Ariel and Tide as well as personal care brand Gillette and babycare brand Pampers.

Commenting on the commissioning of the solar plant, Sachin Sharma, plant head â Hyderabad manufacturing site, P&G India said environmental sustainability is core to P&Gâs operations and increasing the use of renewable electricity and improving energy efficiencies is a critical part of that journey.

headline: No containment zones yet in hotspot Hyderabad
content: HYDERABAD: Two weeks after the Telangana high court directed the government to create containment zones in areas where Covid-19 cases were high, the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) authorities said they have only identified hotspots and are sanitising for now.The civic body had played a key role in maintaining containment zones, disinfecting localities, tracking contacts of Covid-19 patients to get them tested during the first wave, but residents and health experts said it must do the same, if not more now. âWe had containment zones during the first wave because there was no awareness about the pandemic. Now, we have the vaccine and people are aware of the precautions they need to take,â said Dr Rambabu, chief entomologist, GHMC.Officials, however, informed that they have a list of Covid-19 hotspots, and they are requesting locals to voluntarily restrict movement in and out of such places and are urging them to follow the safety protocol. âWe have identified hotspots and have instructed gated communities to impose restrictions,â said an official, under whose jurisdiction a gated community, in Madinaguda, reported 121 positive Covid-19 cases.Health experts, on the other hand, pointed out that GHMCâs decision to not mark containment zones might further deteriorate the situation. âThe civic body must impose some restrictions to contain the spread in the second wave. We need to create containment zones and restrict movement, especially in public places,â said Dr Satya Prakash, consultant pulmonologist.In yet another fresh order on Monday, the Telangana high court expressed its displeasure over the state governmentâs failure in handling second wave of Covid-19 in the state. The court directed it to publicise information on the micro-containment zones through media bulletins and include data of newly declared containment zones.

headline: Hyderabad: Weekly veggie markets, celebrations turn gated communities into Covid clusters
content: HYDERABAD: Weekly vegetable markets, celebrations and public events have worsened the situation in several gated communities in areas such as Kukatpally, Manikonda, Nallagandla and Narsingi, where the number of Covid-19 cases are on the rise.In the last one month, the number of Covid-19 cases have been on a rise across the state. In Telangana, Hyderabad has emerged as the epicentre for all the Covid-19 cases. Amid this, gated communities in the city, especially in the western corridor, are turning out to be hotspots due to laxity.âDuring Holi time, there were public events held within our community wherein food stalls, vendors selling apparels and household items were allowed. There were huge gatherings during that time wherein people didnât follow social distancing norms,â said Pramod Kumar, resident of a gated community in Kukatpally.While few communities have put in place standard operating procedures for common areas and outdoor activities, many are dealing with residents who continue to flout norms related to masks and sanitisation.âThe society has started informing people about the Covid-19 positive cases being reported within the community so that people are vigilant and follow all safety norms. Currently, we have about 83 cases in our community, many of which were reported only in the last 10 days,â said K Balaji, a resident of a gated community in Kokapet.Meanwhile, health wing of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) in the Serilingampally zone is in the process of identifying gated communities that have turned out to be hotspots in the last few weeks.âWe are identifying gated communities in Hafeezpet and surrounding areas after 120 residents were tested positive in My Home Jewel recently. In most gated communities, allowing outsiders has led to the rise in Covid-19 cases. We have ramped up testing in gated communities. Some resident welfare associations have also set up internal isolation centers and are taking up sanitisation drives,â said Dr KS Ravi, assistant medical officer of health, Chandanagar circle, Serilingampally division.

headline: Indian crew aboard Ever Given receive visitors for first time since ship refloating
content:
This was the first time a photo of the seafarers was made available

HYDERABAD: Indian crew members aboard the Ever Given had visitors for the first time since the ship ran aground and subsequently refloated in the Suez Canal on March 29. The crew had been subject to investigation and enquiries by various agencies. This was also the first time a photograph of the seafarers has been made available.

General secretary and treasurer of Mumbai-based National Union of Indian Seafarers ( Nusi ) said the visit to Ever Given, now stationed at Lake of Great Distress, was facilitated by the London-based International Transport Workers Federation (ITF).

âRepresentatives of a local affiliated trade union of seafarers in Egypt boarded the ship and expressed solidarity on behalf of the ITF...This will come as a morale booster to the seafarers as they will know that the shipping community is concerned about their welfare. If they need any legal support, that may also be provided,â Serang, who is also the ITF vice-chair for south Asia, told TOI.

The captain and crew onboard informed the two Egyptian trade union representatives that they had no problem regarding wages, food or provisions. âThey fully understand the situation. Two seafarers â the second engineer and electrician are being signed off and their reliever will join soon which is a positive support from the Egyptian authorities. The crew are keen to resume sailing soon. The ITF team also delivered internet devices to the crew,â Serang said.

It may be mentioned that the Ever Given was seized by the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) over the issue of the shipâs owner unwilling to pay a compensation of nearly one billion dollars for the revenue loss it suffered because of the vessel being stuck in the Suez Canal for six days.

headline: Storm-water drains in city to get facelift with Rs 850 crore
content:
Secunderabad: After a gap of nearly three decades storm-water drains in Secunderabad GHMC Zone will get a facelift under the âStrategic Nala Development Planâ (SNDP). A stretch of 50km has been identified in the zone.

Municipal Administration and Urban Development (MA&UD) department on Monday issued administrative sanction orders to worth Rs 858 crore for re-modellling the entire storm-water drain system covering Greater Hyderabad and its periphery. The project also includes widening of bridges and culverts on storm-water drains. Of the total sum allotted, about Rs 163 crore will be spent on storm-water drains in Secunderabad Zone.

After last yearâs floods, locals had pleaded with MAUD minister, KT Rama Rao to take up works on the Patny Nala in Secunderabad. Secunderabad Cantonment MLA, G Sayanna and SCB ward members had also complained about the problems to the minister then.

âOver 2,000 families of Patny Nagar, Rasoolpura, and abutting areas face problems every year during monsoon due to overflowing of Patny nala. They will get a major relief due to the allocation of Rs 10 crore for remodelling of the nala under SNDP,â G Sayanna told TOI.

Remodelling of Nagamaiah Kunta nala, Kalasiguda nala, widening of nala between Padma Colony Shivanand nagar (Tilak Nagar bridge), nala atMarriott Hotel, and widening of bridges at Ranigunj bus depot, Vidyanagar, Buddha Bhavan and Kavadiguda, will also be taken up with SNDP funds.

headline: Farmer, wife hacked to death by relatives in Telangana
content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A 50-year-old farmer and his wife were hacked to death by their relatives at Neredugommu mandal in Nalgonda district on Monday. After the preliminary investigation police identified the accused and said that land dispute was the reason for the murder. The victims were Vankunavath Somani (50) and Vankunavath Bulli (45) from Buggathanda village in Neredugommu mandal.

On Sunday night, the couple slept in front of their house and at around 1 am on Monday, they were hacked and stabbed to death by a group of people. âBothndied while they were still in their beds,â Dindi circle inspector Venkateswarulu said. Alerted by the villagers, Neredugommu police rushed to the spot and clues team was called for collection of forensic evidence. During the preliminary probe, police found out that Somani and Bichya had a land dispute with the family of Somaniâs late brother, Lachya.

âWe have identified the accused as Vankunavath Suresh (25) and his brother Vankunavath Ganesh, nephews of Somani, and their associates. The accused assaulted the couple when they were in deep sleep, with an axe, knives and iron rods. The victims died on the spot due to excessive bleeding,â the inspector said.

After the murder, police set up a picket in the village to prevent retaliatory violence from the victimâs family. Some of the accused have been taken into custody and a man hunt was launched to nab the absconding accused. A case of murder has been booked.

headline: Police arrest seven for extortion
content: Hyderabad: Seven persons were arrested by Banjara Hills police since they allegedly extorted Rs 1,000 from a cab driver in Indira Nagar. Police said 7 cross dressed persons stopped his vehicle and forcefully snatched Rs 1,000. tnn

headline: Clash erupts between TRS, ABVP workers in Sircilla
content:
Hyderabad: Workers of TRS and ABVP were involved in clashes at Sircilla âs Ellanthukunta village when Telangana industries minister KT Rama Rao visited the village on Monday. The minister was taking a tour of the village which falls under his assembly constituency.

Following the ministerâs participation and address at the Rythu Vedika event in Ellanthukunta, ABVP workers staged a ârasta rokoâ protest, obstructing the ministerâs convoy. ABVP workers were agitating, demanding job notifications. The activists who were involved in the protest were taken into custody and brought to Ellanthukunta police station.

While at the police station, TRS workers came in to lodge a complaint against the protesters and soon a clash erupted between the two groups, according to Sircilla DSP Chandra Sekhar. The vehicle of a TRS worker was damaged during the clash between workers of the two parties. Unable to control the mob, Ellanthukunta SI Mahesh Goud asked senior officials to intervene and send reinforcements.

The situation was finally brought under control after tempers on both sides subsided. Police appealed to both groups not to resort to violence. âAround 20 to 30 ABVP workers came from other places in the state. We are in the process of identifying them all and cases will be registered,â the Sircilla DSP said.

headline: Two arrested for robbing a woman
content: Hyderabad: Two persons who allegedly robbed a woman in Meerpet few days ago were arrested. Police said that the accused S Chinna and V Srinu after consuming liquor came to the victim and forcefully snatcher her 2.5 tolas of gold chain and Rs 2,000 cash. tnn

headline: SR appeals to guest workers not to panic
content:
Guest workers wait at Chennai Central station on Monday. Photo by B A Raju

CHENNAI: Southern Railway on Tuesday appealed to guest workers not to panic and assured them that trains will continue to be operated from major stations to their native states.

The appeal comes as a large number of workers are reaching railway stations like MGR Chennai Central and Tambaram to return home fearing a lockdown in view of rising Covid-19 cases.

The zone will operate 17 trains from MGR Central in a week. They include three trains to Bihar, 10 to West Bengal, two to Odisha, two to Uttar Pradesh. There will be a train from Tambaram to Assam, one each from Puducherry to West Bengal and Odisha, one train from Nagercoil to West Bengal and two trains from Trichy to West Bengal.

headline: TN lawyer elected BCI vice-chairman
content:
Advocate S Prabakaran

CHENNAI: Designated senior advocate S Prabakaran was elected vice-chairman of the Bar Council of India ( BCI ) on Tuesday.

Prabakaran, who represents the Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry at BCI, was elected unopposed, as no other member had filed nomination till the deadline of 3pm on Tuesday.

A veteran lawyer who was three-time president of the Madras High Court Advocates Association ( MHAA ), Prabakaran heads the Tamil Nadu Advocates Association now. He was elected to the BCI for a second consecutive term two years ago.

In an official statement released on Tuesday, returning officer Suresh Chandra Shrimali said: âSince there no other nomination has been filed by any other member, there is no need to proceed further with the election process. S Prabakaran is declared elected unopposed for the post of vice-chairman, Bar Council of India. Since the post fell vacant due to the resignation of S A Deshmukh, the tenure of Prabakaran will be only for the remaining period â one year â as per the BCI rules.â

As per the April 19 election notification, the last date for nomination was till 3pm on April 20. In case of a contest, the election was to be held on May 2 and the result was to be declared the same day.

headline: Covid-19 surge: PMK leader urges Tamil Nadu govt to shut down Tasmac liquor outlets
content: CHENNAI: PMK leader S Ramadoss on Tuesday urged the Tamil Nadu government to shut down Tasmac outlets in the state to prevent the spread of Covid-19 Ramadoss tweeted that the night curfew announced by the government was not enough to control the spread of coronavirus.He stated that more stringent measures should be taken to ensure that livelihood of the public was not affected.

headline: Covid-19: Vedanta offers to supply oxygen from its locked Sterlite Copper premises in Tuticorin
content: CHENNAI: Metals major Vedanta Limited on Tuesday offered to support the Centre and various states, including Tamil Nadu, in their fight against Covid-19 by supplying oxygen from its locked Sterlite Copper premises in Tuticorin There are two oxygen plants, which can function independently, and supply around 1,000 tonne per day (tpd) of oxygen to various state governments in view of the urgent need to offer its support for the governmentsâ efforts to meet rising demand."The two plants have a capacity of 500 tpd each. As and when the permission is granted, we can quickly get one plant ready and start oxygen supplies to the needy states. By that time, the second plant too would be ready to enable us supply 1,000 tpd at this critical time," sources in Sterlite Copper told TOI.Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Sunday, after reviewing the Covid-19 situation in the state, directed the industries department to give temporary licences to industrial units which are willing to supply oxygen during the critical time.Sterlite Copper, part of the Vedanta Group, has reached out to Union health and family welfare minister Harsh Vardhan and the Tamil Nadu chief minister through separate letters conveying its offer to help. The company has also filed a petition outlining this offer of support in the Supreme Court, in view of the ongoing legal proceedings.âThe Sterlite Copper plant in Tuticorin contains two oxygen plants, with a combined capacity of producing 1,000 tonnes of Oxygen daily. We would like to now offer these facilities for your use, towards ensuring that there is no lack of this vital commodity in the nation, and also to join hands with the commendable efforts of our PM at this critical juncture,â Pankaj Kumar, CEO, Sterlite Copper said in his letter to the Union health minister.âWe would be grateful to be allowed this opportunity to support the nationâs needs. Our staff stand prepared to get these two plants operational in the shortest possible time and begin dispatching oxygen to the critical areas as per your direction,â he said in the letter.In a separate letter to Palaniswami, Kumar said the Covid-19 cases were increasing at a rapid rate in Tamil Nadu and other states. Most of the state governments have been facing a shortage of oxygen supply to treat the increasing number of Covid patients.âThe oxygen plant is presently lying shut owing to the orders passed by the TNPCB and the state governmentâ¦ This is a humble request to grant us the necessary permission and allow us to run the oxygen plant, which will be instrumental in supporting the state governments in these critical times,â he said in his letter to the CM.

headline: Madurai MP urges Union minister to renew health cover for Covid-19 warriors
content: MADURAI: Madurai MP Su Venkatesan has written to Union health minister Harsh Vardhan urging him to renew the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Package Insurance Scheme for Covid-19 warriors. The scheme expired on March 24.Expressing shock over not renewing it for 27 days, the MP asked the government to renew it without delay.The MP stated that the scheme had covered public healthcare providers who may have to be in direct contact and care of Covid-19 cases and who may be at risk of being impacted by this.It also covered private hospital staffs, volunteers, workers of local bodies, contract and daily wage workers, ad hoc and outsourced staff requisitioned by state and central hospitals and autonomous hospitals of central and state governments and Union territories drafted for Covid 19 related responsibilities.âThese frontline workers have earned much respect among the people as âCovid warriorsâ for their sacrifices during this crisis deserve more empathy from the government,â the MP said.He said a letter from secretary, department of health and family welfare, Rajesh Bhushan to all states and Union territories (D.O No Z 21020/16/2020-PH) dated March 24 stated that only 287 claims had been approved and settled by the insurer. He expressed concern that many eligible claims had not been processed in a proper manner and urged the ministry to issue clear cut guidelines to the insurer and to the respective governments for effective implementation of the insurance scheme.The MP quoted the letter as stating that claims under the scheme were eligible for coverage only till midnight on March 24 and that the last date of filing such claims with all requirements is April 24. âIt raises the question over the fate of frontline workers who lost their precious lives after the midnight of March 24 till renewal of the insurance scheme or introduction of a new scheme,â he said.Venkatesan said that expiry of the scheme and delay in steps to be taken by the Centre to renew the policy or bring a new scheme has caused much concern among frontline workers who are in the forefront in fighting second wave of Covid throughout the country.âThis laxity on the part of the government is unfortunate. Such inaction has dented the morale of frontline workers,â he said and requested the minister to take care of these aspects and render justice to Covid warriors.

headline: Tasmac liquor shops to remain closed in Chennai on two days in May
content:
A Tasmac liquor shop

CHENNAI: All Tasmac liquor outlets in Chennai will remain closed on May 1 and May 2.

While the liquor shops will be shut on May 1 (Saturday) for May Day, the liquor outlets will also remain closed on May 2 (Sunday) due to the counting of votes polled in the April 6 assembly election.

In a press release here on Tuesday, Chennai district collector R. Seethalakshmi said that there shall be no sale of liquor on these days.

headline: Chennai: Stalker gets life sentence for stabbing
content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: A mahila court in the city awarded life sentence to a stalker who stabbed a colleague on her way to work in 2014.

Judge M Rajalakshmi found Saravanan, now 27, of Kolathur, guilty of attacking the woman after she avoided him and rejected his proposal. Saravan has to pay a fine of ?5,000.

Saravanan and the survivor worked in the same firm. After she rejected his proposal, he confronted her on May 7, 2014, and stabbed her on the road when she tried to avoid him. Onlookers had rescued the woman and admitted her to a hospital.

headline: End semester exams to be open-book tests for engineering students
content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Following the announcement of open book test for students of four campuses of Anna University , the university on Monday announced that students in constituent colleges, regional campuses and affiliated colleges will also write their semester exams as open book, online-proctored test in May.

âDuring the exam, students can refer to course materialin physicalform aswell as from the web. However, getting answers from others in any way or form andgroup discussions will be considered as malpractice,â a circular to affiliated colleges from the centre for academic courses, Anna University, said.

All questions will be analytical with no direct answers from the text books or reference books. Students need to write the exam on paper and upload the answer sheets after the exams. For final year students, the exams will be conducted online with multiple choice-based questions.

Anna Universityâs former vice-chancellor E Balagurusamy said open book test is a very good concept and popular method of examination. âOpen book tests need to be conducted in a controlled environment and students should complete the test within a specific period of time.Withanalyticalquestions, one cannot copy the answer from the book. Only intelligent ones can shine in open book tests as one needs to know where exactly they should look for answers in thebook,â hesaid.He,however, said conducting open book tests across the state would be a challenge as the internet connection speed may not fast everywhere.

V E Annamalai, principal of SSN College of Engineering in Chennai, said students need to understand the concepts and have to apply the knowledge in the tests. âDespite having books, students may not be able to answer the questions. Conventional exams test the knowledge of the students, whereas open book tests will test their understanding and application,â he said.

B Chidambararajan, principal of SRM Valliammai Engineering College said the open book test would be a huge shift for students from MCQs-based exams. âThe pass percentage may drop. These students have traditionally prepared for memory based exams. If the university asks analytical questions, a majority of them will struggle even to identify the units from which the question is asked,â he said.

Deemed universities such as Sastra have been conducting open book tests. âWe can get creative while framing questions. There wonât be onecorrectanswer anditwill test the studentsâ creativity and conceptual understanding,â said S Vaidyasubramaniam, vice-chancellor of SASTRA.

Colleges such as Loyola had open book test for the first internal assessment, but is switching back to proctored online tests for semester exams based on feedback from parents. âParents feel conventional exams are the best way to test students. We havetotrain our faculty toset questions for open-book exams and create awareness among the parent, as it will equip students to develop problem solving ability and applying concepts,â said Thomas Amirtham, principal of Loyola College .

headline: Krishna water to flow into Chennai from May first week
content:
A file photo shows Krishna river water entering the city through a canal near Sriperambadur

CHENNAI: The Poondi reservoir, one of the five supplying the city, is set to receive Krishna river water from neighbouring Andhra Pradesh soon.

A senior PWD official said the department planned to request the AP authorities to release Krishna water from the first week of next month. âThis will refill the Poondi reservoir. Kandaleru reservoir in Andhra Pradesh has 47 tmcft (thousand million cubic feet) of water against its full capacity of 68.030 tmcft.â

On Monday, the Poondi reservoir had a storage of 1,497 mcft (million cubic feet), or 46.33% of its full capacity of 3,231 mcft. Most of the water that flowed into the reservoir following copious rain during the last monsoon was released to the reservoirs at Red Hills and Chembarambakkam. The two, which now have 3,006 mcft and 2,983 mcft - 91.09% and 81.84% of their capacity â are the main sources of supply to the city water supply network.

The 250 million litres a day ( MLD ) that Metrowater draws from Chembarambakkam is distributed after treatment which involves adding minerals. While 162.36MLD drawn from Red Hills goes into the system and supplied to residents in central Chennai after treatment at the Kilpauk Water Works, another 103.23MLD drawn from Red Hills is pumped into the supply network through the treatment plant at Puzhal.

Besides, the Chennai Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (CMWSSB), popular as Metrowater, also pumps about 6.47 MLD into the Surapet treatment plant for supply to city residents, said an official.

The PWD official said once the water is released from Andhra Pradesh, the repair work on the canal will be suspended temporarily. As per the original plan, the duration for completing the repair on the canal is one year, the official added.

headline: Tasmac to issue tokens to curb crowding, cuts sale time by 1 hour
content:
A recent photo shows a crowded Tasmac shop near Pallikaranai

CHENNAI: Under fire for having allowed unregulated crowding at retail liquor outlets, Tasmac has now come out with stringent covid-appropriate norms.

In a series of instructions to its district managers, the office of Tasmac managing director introduced the token system to ensure that no Tasmac shop will have more than five customers at a time. The sale time has been reduced by one hour so as to wind up sales at 9pm.

Bars will also down shutters at 9pm. No tokens will be issued after 8pm. âTiming must be mentioned on the tokens, and no token would be issued after 8pm. Shops must be compulsorily shut at 9pm," a senior Tasmac official said.

These regulations are to preempt repeat of May 8, 2020 ruling of the Madras high court ordering closure of liquor outlets across the state, after crowds surged when shops reopened after 40-day pandemic break, throwing pandemic protocol to the winds.

The present instructions say barricades should be placed about 200 metres from each shop, and prohibit customers from consuming liquor in public places. Besides a ban on bulk sale of liquor, no-mask-no-liquor norms have also been brought in. The management has empowered district managers to recruit more temporary hands to enforce these norms. The liquor sale protocol will come into effect immediately.

There will be circles at 6 feet gap within the barricaded 200 metres so that customers can maintain social distancing, the circular said, adding that customers must follow a single line so that not more than five people will be standing in front of counters.

Also, the shelf life of beer and wine stocks would be checked before sale. "Sedimented wine and stocks of beer that have completed 6 months should not be sold and kept separately, which would be returned to godown," the communication to Tasmac district managers said.

headline: Getting up, close and personal with performing artists
content:
Carnatic musician Savita Narasimhan has always been keen on documenting and archiving everything related to the performing arts of south India. And thatâs the vision behind âNotes to myselfâ, a docu-series that delves into the lives, creative processes and choices of artists.

"Documentation and archiving neednât be only of the past. It can be as things happen as I believe an artistâs entire career should be documented for their journey to be captured," says Savita, who founded MOPA (Museum of Performing Arts) Foundation in 2017. The first episode of âNotes To Myselfâ, the organisationâs flagship project, featuring Bharatanatyam exponent Leela Samson, will be uploaded on their YouTube channel on April 24.

"I wanted to archive music, dance and theatre of south India as I feel so much of it has been lost. And what has been preserved is not easily accessible to all," says Savita.

MOPAâs first project was an exhibition to mark the centenary year of legendary Bharatanatyam dancer T Balasaraswati. "It was exhibited in five locations, including Bengaluru and Singapore," says Savita, whose other projects came to a standstill because of the pandemic.

In January, MOPA launched its YouTube channel. "Though I want to establish a physical museum, it will take time. And the pandemic has pushed all museums to look at the digital platform, so I thought why not start archiving and presenting," says Savita.

So MOPA compiled all the footage on Balasaraswati into smaller capsules and put it out every Saturday. "For me, an archive needs to be easily accessible and this is one way of doing it," says Savita, who then came up with the idea of a docu-series on living legends.

"There are so many great artists in this part of the world. We see them on stage but donât know them. I wanted to give an insight into their thought processes, and life choices. What fascinates me is the human element and we have tried to highlight it in the series," says Savita, who began working on it in last December.

The first season, featuring Leela Samson. Bombay Jayashri, T M Krishna and Pradeep Kumar has been shot by V Gowrishankar. "We have tried to match the personality to the location. For instance, we shot Leela Samson at a gazebo in Kingsley in Chetpet since she is a nature love. For Bombay Jayashri, we got a home that had a huge library as she wanted books around her," says Savita.

Each artist has spoken about his/her work as well as important turning points in life. "Everyone knows Leela Samson moved from Kalakshetra to Delhi. But do you know she had already been cast as Sita in Rukmini Deviâs production and why she moved? The docu-series will tell you all that more," says Savita.

headline: Charge of temples: Tamil Nadu, citizens need to find a fine balance together
content:
Its competency is under question in the light of mismanagement of temples, theft of idols and lack of protecti... Read More

By: R S Raveendhren

CHENNAI: A section of people wants to free Hindu temples from government control. They want temples and their properties to be handed over to devotees to ensure better administration and management. These groups are also suggesting that the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) board under the Government of Tamil Nadu be disbanded.

There are three major grounds on which attacks are being launched against the HR&CE department. Its competency is under question in the light of mismanagement of temples, theft of idols and lack of protection to temple properties.

In January 2018, a response filed by the HR&CE department in the Madras high court stated that 1,204 sculptures belonging to 387 temples had been stolen since 1992. The laxity of the government in protecting the priceless idols, jewels, and sculptures of Hindu temples and its cavalier approach towards preservation of ancient heritage have sowed seeds of mistrust and shaken the confidence of the common man.

To understand the issues of the present, we need to delve into the past, looking into why the state control came into place.

Legend has it that in the 7th century, Nandanar (one of the 63 Nayanmars), was denied entry into temples for being an outcast and Lord Sivalokanathar (Shiva) at the Tirupungur temple commanded Nandi (the bull) to move away from the gate to unobstruct Nandanarâs view of the shrine. Discrimination while entering temples was a reality when the kings reigned, and the right to worship and access to temples remained elusive for a long time. Apart from this, there were complaints about mismanagement, misappropriation of temple funds, and failure to protect temple properties.

Many believe that the British introduced the Madras Regulation VII of 1817, which brought temples under the control of the government as an agenda for colonisation and conversions. Temples in the south possessed massive land and wealth, with this regulation the British could monitor grants and endowments to them. In 1840, there was a directive to return temples to their trustees. This had something to do with Christian missionaries not liking the idea of managing Hindu temples.

In 1922, the Hindu Paripalanam Act was proposed by Ramraya Ningar, the king of Panagal, when he took charge as the chief minister of the Madras Presidency. He attempted to bring temples under the control of the government. In 1927, the HR&CE board was constituted and vested with the power to control and supervise administration of temples.

Fight against prejudices

Tamil Nadu may be a land with rich spiritual and cultural values, yet the right to worship at temples were secured only after the stateâs intervention.

Following the success of the temple entry movement by Periyar, A Vaidhyanatha Iyer headed the Madurai Temple Entry Movement in 1939 to facilitate the entry of the oppressed classes into Madurai Meenakshi temple. This was the time when the Temple Entry Authorisation and Indemnity Act of 1939 by C Rajagopalachari (the then CM of Madras Presidency) and Temple Entry Authorisation Act, 1947 by Omandoor P Ramasami Reddiar (first CM of Tamil Nadu) were passed. The legislation reflected the intent of the government to democratise temple worship and give all people access.

Present problem

In spite of damning allegations, the Tamil Nadu government chooses to stay silent on the issue. One of the campaigns against government control claims that the HR&CE Act, 1959 is ultra vires the Constitution and Hindu temples are selectively being subjected to state intervention. This is an attempt to mislead people. The Supreme Court had upheld the constitutional validity of the 1951 law which is its earlier version. Further, religious institutions and practices of Muslims, Christians and Sikhs are not immune to state intervention. It is a well-settled law that under Article 25 and Article 26 of the Constitution, the state has the right to regulate and manage the governance of temples.

It must be noted that the HR&CE department serves not just as a custodian of Hindu temples but also as a progressive transformative tool for society, managing eduational institutions, social welfare organisations and hospitals. The questions to be asked are: Can citizensâ groups seek any redemption of sovereign functions in their favour citing inefficient administration? Does this not tantamount to challenging the authority of a democratic state?
